result.execSummary:
Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Cortez D Britton

records.addlTxt: Cases called: 16CF425, 14CF388, 17CF321, 17CF320, Defendant Cortez D. Britton in court with attorney Steven James Sarbacker.  Crystal N Long appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court reviewed the rights & elements. Defendant pled no contest to counts 1&3 in 16CF425. Court found defendant guilty, entered judgment. Sentence on count 1 is 3 years probation, Conditions: 6 months jail commencing Oct. 1, 2018 at 7 pm. Huber granted, may serve Sauk or Adams County Jail. $268 costs. Complete an AODA assessment and follow through with any treatment recommendations. Submit DNA sample. No contact L.T. except for child care issues. On count 3, Court imposed 45 days jail with 41 days jail credit for time served. 24 month revocation, 24 month IID. Complete an AODA assessment and follow through with any treatment recommendations. $1,694 fine. Sixty days to pay fine or set up a payment plan with Clerk of Courts. Submit DNA sample. All other counts and cases read in and dismissed.

filed by Court Reporter Chris Champeau, April 29, 2015 motion to dismiss

Evidence was not sent to the Crime Lab in a timely fashion. Testing has not been done. Without the testing, the State cannot prove the charges beyond a reasonable doubt, at this time. Case dismissed with prejudice.

Attorney Adam Raabe appeared. Crystal N Long appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Defendant had filed a Demand for Speedy Trial. Cout noted the State filed a Motion to Dismiss. ADA Long stated Crime Lab isn't able to analyze the evidence in time. Atty. Raabe opposed the motion to dismiss, concerned with the State refiling the case later. Statement by ADA Long. Court noted the speedy trial demand statute states a jury trial can't even be reset. Court found lack of obtaining the evidence on the State's part. Court dismissed the case with prejudice.
